news.title: Jere rallies CAPS United ahead of Highlanders clash
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sports Editor
CAPS United president, Farai Jere believes his team will rise to the occasion when they face Highlanders in the first edition of the Battle of the Cities slated for Barbourfields Stadium on Sunday.
The Battle of the Cities looms with the two main actors Highlanders and CAPS United not at their imperious best.
Makepekepe are in the bottom three with a mere four points from five matches, Bosso are not much better either as they have six points ahead of the eagerly anticipated match.
CAPS United go into the match with their back against the wall after a mini-protest by their fans after the defeat to Ngezi Platinum Stars last Sunday, but club president Jere believes their time is now.
“This is the time when you will see the true CAPS United starting with the Highlanders match, yes we have not started well but we will rise in matches like these and I believe that will spur us onto good things, we have one of the best squads and we are still holding onto our targets,” Jere said.

news.title: WPSL set to kick-off with Bulawayo derby between Highlanders Royals and MPOSA
news.content:
Story by Mthokozisi Dube
THE Women’s Premier Soccer League (WPSL) is set to commence this Saturday, with one of the most anticipated fixtures being the Bulawayo derby between Highlanders Royals and newly promoted Mpopoma Sports Academy (MPOSA).
MPOSA, an ambitious side, is aiming for a strong start in their inaugural season.
This fixture, while traditionally viewed as a standard encounter, takes on added significance as MPOSA has seen a number of players return to their parent clubs following their loan spells.
Notably, former loan player Patience Ndlovu, a Mighty Warriors forward, made her return to Highlanders last season and will be missing from MPOSA’s ranks.
Ndlovu remains optimistic about her former side’s prospects.
“It is a big game, derbies are unpredictable but the girls are raring for the challenge. I have been advising them that it is a normal game,” Ndlovu said.
MPOSA roped in Evans Neta who had a successful stint with the now defunct Bulawayo Queens as their head coach.
“We respect Highlanders. They are a good side but we remain hopeful. We will come out with a positive result. We have had preparations to polish the side and the girls are raring to go,” Neta said.

news.title: BUZ empowers local referees through FIBA level-one course
news.content:
Story by Mthokozisi Dube
THE Basketball Union of Zimbabwe has moved in to capacitate local referees after organising a four-day Federation of International Basketball Associations (FIBA) sanctioned level-one officiating clinic in Bulawayo.
Junior referees from across the six basketball-playing provinces are attending the course meant to equip them with the revolving laws of the game.
The facilitator of the clinic, Tanzania’s Zulfikar Karim said the enthusiasm displayed by officials in attendance will aid in the development of the game.
“It is a big week here in Zimbabwe. The officials are keen to learn and we hope this will improve the game. The officials are grasping new laws of the game and we hope this will spread to the lower levels,” Karim said.

news.title: Battle of the cities, Highlanders set to clash with CAPS United at Barbourfields Stadium
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sports Editor
THE Battle of the Cities has for so long been a platform for beautiful football, with the clash between Highlanders and CAPS United erupting at Barbourfields Stadium on Sunday.
Never mind the two teams’ waning fortunes in recent years, the match is still one of the most anticipated in the land and never disappoints.
The clash produces heroes and villains and over the years, it has written many memories in the minds of spectators.
The back-to-back league clashes of 2004 stand out when the two teams played an exciting three-all draw at Barbourfields before Bosso edged Makepekepe 4-3 at the National Sports Stadium in the reverse encounter.
Even though the Green Machine went on to win the league that year, on the fateful day, Tapuwa Kapini was the hero while Witness Munkuli was the villain.
Many such encounters have happened over the years and this Sunday more of the same is expected as the two age-old giants clash, even though they seem to be fading, they usually save the best when they meet.

news.title: ERSL secures first major sponsor in over 20 years
news.content:
Story by Mercy Bofu-Matinha
ZIFA Eastern Region Division One soccer league has received a lifeline after securing a sponsorship deal with cigarette manufacturer, Pacific Storm.
The league has not had a title sponsor for more than two decades, hence the excitement following the official launch of the deal over the weekend at Mucheke Stadium in Masvingo.
“We are excited as players that for the first time we have a sponsor, it is our hope that the deal will ensure improvement in terms of our matches. We had a lot of challenges and many times it would then demotivate us as players, but with this development, we are looking forward to exciting times,” Tenax Player, Jambo Joseph Tatenda said.
“The coming in of Pacific Storm as a sponsor has motivated us a lot as players. For me, it is been six years playing in ERSL and we did not have a sponsor, now all teams will put in more effort and for players, we now know that in the end, if you play well, definitely there will be rewards,” Wangu Mazodze Captain, Lucky Itimu said.
The League’s Chairperson, Wisdom Simba and ZIFA Chief Executive Officer, Yvonne Mapika Manwa concurred that the deal will go a long way in improving competition in the league.
“This is a huge step for us as the Eastern Region Soccer League and the deal will focus, beyond the core package, on branding and marketing of the league. This will also motivate our players because now they know we have a sponsor. In terms of value, currently, I am not able to share the exact details of its worth but we are happy as the executive,” Simba said.
“This partnership is a testament of what ERSL is doing as a league and it is also a reflection of what the ZIFA itself is, I think more than anything we appreciate that Pacific Storm has come in as a pioneer to sponsor this league. This is a partnership where we as the football industry are bringing in something to the corporate world while they are also bringing something very important for us,” Mapika Manwa said.
